Style of the letters. — Some of the letters were expected by the writer to become public property, and were formal in tone and studied in diction; but the great mass have the charm of spontaneity and are written in the language of conversation, the sermo fa- miliaris or cottidianus (XXXII.) Among the chief stylistic peculiarities of the letters are: (a) the fre- quent use of Greek words and phraseS‚ especially as technical terms or to make the letter unintelligible to those who might tamper with it, but also in some measure, perhapS, an affectation, although it should be noted that most of the Greek occurs in letters to Atti- cus, who sic Graece loquebatur ut Athenis uatus videre- tur(Nep. Att. 4. 1); (b) the prevalence and variety of diminutive formations; (c) the freedom of composition with per and sub. (d) Here should be mentioned, τοο, the epistolary tenses.
